title: Fionn Carr
text:
Fionn Carr (born 17 December 1985) is an <a href="Ireland">Irish</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player. He plays primarily as a <a href="Wing%20%28rugby%20union%29">wing</a> but can also play at <a href="Fullback%20%28rugby%20union%29">fullback</a>. Carr played most of his professional career for Irish province <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a> in the <a href="Pro14">Pro12</a>, and he holds the team record for most tries scored. He also played for another Irish province, <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a> in the past. Carr has represented Ireland at Schools, Under 19 and Under 21 level, as well as at international 'A' level and the <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">Ireland national rugby sevens team</a>.
Carr currently plays at amateur level for <a href="Naas%20RFC">Naas</a> in the <a href="All-Ireland%20League%20%28rugby%20union%29">All-Ireland League</a>. He is also the backs coach for <a href="Catholic%20University%20School">Catholic University School</a> in Dublin.
Youth.
Carr started playing rugby with <a href="Naas%20RFC">Naas</a> at underage levels. At school level Carr played for <a href="Newbridge%20College">Newbridge College</a>. While at Newbridge, Carr played for the junior cup team once, and the senior cup team twice. Carr subsequently won a rugby scholarship to <a href="University%20College%20Dublin">University College Dublin</a> where he studied Arts. He left the <a href="UCD%20RFC">UCD rugby team</a> in his second year of college and joined <a href="Blackrock%20College%20RFC">Blackrock College</a>.
Professional club career.
Carr played once for <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a> during the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Celtic%20League">2007–08 Celtic League</a>, starting on the wing against <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a>.
Connacht.
After finishing in <a href="University%20College%20Dublin">UCD</a>, Carr signed for the western province of <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a>. He was the top try-scorer for Connacht during the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Celtic%20League">2008–09 Celtic League</a> campaign, scoring eight tries in the league. This tally put him one behind the top try-scorer <a href="Thom%20Evans">Thom Evans</a>. He also scored three tries for the team in six appearances in the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20European%20Challenge%20Cup">2008–09 European Challenge Cup</a>. He ended his first stint at Connacht at the end of the 2010-11 season with 34 tries, 22 of them in the league and 12 in the <a href="European%20Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a>. At the time this made him the province's all-time top try-scorer.
Return to Leinster.
Carr joined <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a> for the start of the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Pro%2012">2011–12 season</a>. He made his first appearance for the team since the 2007–08 season against the <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a>. He made his first ever appearance in the <a href="Heineken%20Cup">Heineken Cup</a> on 20 November 2011, against the <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a>. In his first season back in his native province, he played 18 times in the league, with 3 of those appearances being from the bench, scoring 5 tries. He also made 2 appearances from the bench in the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Heineken%20Cup">2011–12 Heineken Cup</a>, as Leinster won the competition.
The following season, Carr played 16 times for the province, but did not play in the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Heineken%20Cup%20pool%20stage">Heineken Cup pool stages</a> or the successful <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20European%20Challenge%20Cup">Amlin Cup campaign</a>, with all of his appearances coming in <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Pro%2012">the Pro 12</a>. He scored only 3 tries, with those coming against <a href="Dragons%20%28rugby%20union%29">Newport Gwent Dragons</a>, <a href="Cardiff%20Blues">Cardiff Blues</a> and <a href="Zebre">Zebre</a>.
He left Leinster at the end of the 2012–13 season, having scored 8 tries in his two seasons there, all of them coming in the league.
Return to Connacht.
Carr returned to Connacht for the 2013–14 season, having turned down the offer of a new contract with Leinster. His return debut came in the opening game of the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Pro12">2013–14 Pro12</a> against <a href="Zebre">Zebre</a>. Carr started the game and scored a try. He played his first ever Heineken Cup game for Connacht on 11 October 2013, against <a href="Saracens%20F.C.">Saracens</a> in <a href="Galway">Galway</a>. Carr left Connacht at the end of the 2015-16 season.
All Ireland League.
Carr joined <a href="Naas%20RFC">Naas RFC</a> in the All Ireland League in the summer of 2016.
International career.
Carr played for Ireland at various under-age levels, including Under-19 and Under-21.
Carr also played for Ireland's second tier international team, which is currently known as <a href="Ireland%20Wolfhounds">Ireland Wolfhounds</a> and was previously Ireland A. His first appearance for Ireland A came in a <a href="2009%20Churchill%20Cup">2009 Churchill Cup</a> against <a href="Canada%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Canada</a>. He also started against the <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a> on 31 January 2010, in a 17–13 loss. In 2010, the Irish Times referred to Carr as "Perhaps the fastest winger in the country one of Ireland’s outstanding performers against England Saxons this season". Despite his strong try-scoring record while with the province, Carr did not receive a full international cap.
Carr played for the <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">Ireland national rugby sevens team</a> in the Rugby Europe <a href="2017%20Sevens%20Grand%20Prix%20Series">2017 Sevens Grand Prix Series</a>, playing as the starting centre. Carr's performance in the 2017 Grand Prix helped the team qualify for the <a href="2018%20Hong%20Kong%20Sevens">2018 Hong Kong Sevens</a> and the <a href="2018%20Rugby%20World%20Cup%20Sevens">2018 Rugby World Cup Sevens</a>.
